text: Parallel compression is a technique where you blend a heavily compressed signal with the original uncompressed one. This adds punch and sustain without squashing dynamics.
When EQing vocals, cut muddy frequencies around 200-400Hz, and boost some air above 10kHz if needed. Always use subtractive EQ first.
A plate reverb is great for vocals because it adds brightness and clarity. Use a decay time around 1.2s and high-pass the reverb tail at 200Hz.
Sidechain compression is often used in EDM to duck the bass when the kick hits. Set a fast attack and a medium release for a classic pumping effect.
Additive EQ involves boosting specific frequencies to enhance a sound. It's useful after subtractive EQ to add presence or clarity.
Bus processing lets you apply effects to a group of tracks, like compressing all drums together. This helps glue the mix and control peaks.
